p: Achillea millefolium (known as yarrow) also belongs to the Asteraceae family. It is widely distributed throughout the temperate climates of the Northern hemisphere but is also found in Australia and New Zealand [ 19]. This perennial herb has been used in traditional medicine for centuries as a treatment for hepatobiliary disorders, gastrointestinal complaints, inflammation, wounds, rheumatism, hysteria, as well as internal and external bleeding [ 20]. It was reported that A. millefolium exhibits anxiolytic, anti-inflammatory, tonic, antimicrobial, antispasmodic and diaphoretic properties [ 21, 22]. Additionally, it contains numerous classes of compounds, mainly volatile constituents of essential oil (chamazulene, cineol, camphor, azulene and others), steroids and triterpenes (sitosterol, stigmasterol, campesterol, α- and β-amyrin), and polyphenols (flavonoids: myricetin, quercetin, apigenin, luteolin, kaempferol derivatives and phenolic acids: e.g., chlorogenic, caffeic, p-coumaric and ferulic) [ 23, 24].
